http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Theatre I is a two-semester course in which students learn and demonstrate mastery of theatre academic and performance skills. Theatre II and III are two-semester courses which expand the knowledge and performance base of Theatre I. At the Theatre I level, students will explore theatre fundamentals, analyze and interpret scripts, evaluate artistic work, and use those evaluations to deepen the meaning of their work. In Theatre II and III students will focus on the practical application of skills developed in Theatre I. Students will take on more complex projects and may begin to develop directorial skills. Ultimately, students will make artistic decisions using multiple forms of inspiration, particularly focusing on social, cultural, and historical context. Theatre I contains an introduction to stagecraft skills. Theatre II and III do not develop these stagecraft skills, but the teacher may choose to draw student learning expectations from the Stagecraft I-III Curriculum Framework. Theatre I fulfills the one-half credit fine arts required for graduation. Arkansas Department of Education approval is not required for Theatre I, Theatre II, and Theatre III.
Creating
Students will generate and conceptualize artistic ideas and work.
Create imaginary environments through dramatic activities (e.g., pantomime, mime, improvisation) to develop diverse characters to elicit a specific audience response
Collaborate to prepare an informal or formal performance for a specific audience or specific purpose
Make design choices from a directorial perspective
SLE introduced in Theatre I. Refer to appropriate level of Stagecraft for optional extension of SLE.
Students will organize and develop artistic ideas and work.
Justify choices made in the development of characters, environments, and actions to create a desired effect in a devised or scripted drama/theatre work

Utilize appropriate terminology in regard to stage directions
  • center stage
  • downstage
  • stage left
  • stage right
  • upstage
Develop competencies in various onstage and/or offstage roles

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., actor, director, designer, producer, playwright, technician, stage manager

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Adapt a drama/theatre work for a specific theatre space
SLE introduced in Theatre I. Refer to appropriate level of Stagecraft for optional extension of SLE.
Revise selected theatrical paperwork

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., résumé, rehearsal schedule, audition forms

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Students will refine and complete artistic work.
Refine choices based on self and peer evaluations of artistic work
Performing
Students will analyze, interpret, and select artistic work for presentation.
Analyze a script of literary merit to interpret characters, visual design elements, and cultural/historical significance
Develop a directorial approach to guide actors in making character choices in a drama/theatre work using research of other directors' approaches as a guide
Make artistic choices, based on research from multiple sources of information, in a drama/theatre work with peers
Articulate author's intent using character's objectives and tactics
Make artistic choices based on the relative importance of the elements of drama to a devised or scripted drama/theatre work
Students will develop and refine artistic work for presentation.
Refine a believable, authentic, and relevant performance of a drama/theatre work through more complex physical, vocal, and psychological choices
Investigate diverse methods of creating empathetic characters
Refine theatrical skills and techniques through the rehearsal process
Make artistic choices to refine a drama/theatre work using steps in the acting process

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., analysis, research, vocal/movement choices, character choices, rehearsal

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Cultivate a strong and versatile stage voice
SLE introduced in Theatre I. Refer to appropriate level of Stagecraft for optional extension of SLE.
Enforce appropriate safety practices in theatre

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., personal protective equipment, proper use of tools and chemicals, situational awareness, exit procedures

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Students will convey meaning through the presentation of artistic work.
Convey a specific meaning through a collaborative performance of a devised or scripted drama/theatre work for a specific audience
Create a directorial vision for presentation to peers
Responding
Students will perceive and analyze artistic work.
Evaluate the consequences of a character's decisions and actions
Critique the authenticity of character interactions
Critique the contribution of technical elements to the effectiveness of a production
Analyze dramatic elements of an observed drama/theatre work using more complex theatre terminology
Respond appropriately to a theatrical experience as an audience member
Students will interpret intent and meaning in artistic work.
Compare emotional responses evoked by a variety of genres to interpret the intent of the playwright
SLE introduced in Theatre I. Refer to appropriate level of Stagecraft for optional extension of SLE.
Students will apply criteria to evaluate artistic work.

Develop more complex criteria using theatre terminology to evaluate performances and/or designs
  • peer
  • self
  • stage, film, and/or television
Justify a position taken on the artistic merit of a drama/theatre work
Connecting
Students will synthesize and relate knowledge and personal experiences to make art.
Synthesize personal experience and theatre knowledge to create a drama/theatre work
Employ knowledge of acting theories (e.g., internal, external, integrated, method) to increase the impact of student-created drama/theatre work
Students will relate artistic ideas and works with societal, cultural, and historical context to deepen understanding.
Justify personal artistic choices based on societal, cultural, and historical contexts

Evaluate the influence (e.g., design choices, acting choices, directing choices) of cultural perspectives and theatrical conventions/practices on the creation of a specific informal or formal presentation of a drama/theatre work
Explore the intention of the playwright and/or director to influence the beliefs, attitudes, and actions of the audience
Demonstrate cultural sensitivity through appropriate response to the artistic work of others
Create an informal or formal presentation of a drama/theatre work reflecting community values and beliefs
Employ knowledge of theatre history to refine student-created drama/theatre work
Utilize other art forms and media to create a directorial vision
SLE introduced in Theatre I. Refer to appropriate level of Stagecraft for optional extension of SLE.
Assess the impact of technology on a specific drama/theatre work
